Evaluation of Team Members’ Performance

) Purpose: This IRM section describes the process and procedures for working team cases in Appeals. These cases are received from Large Business and and International (LB&I) and are generally assigned to an Appeals Team Case Leader (ATCL). However, in some instances a senior Appeals Officer (AO) is assigned as a team leader. Therefore, these procedures are used by both ATCLs and AOs who are team leaders on a team case. (
) Audience: Appeals. (
) Policy Owner: Appeals Policy is under Director, Case and Operations Support. (
) Program Owner: Appeals Policy is the program office responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to the Appeals organization. (

) Contact Information: Appeals employees should follow established procedures on How to Contact an Analyst. Other employees should contact the Product Content Owner shown on the Product Catalog Information page for this IRM. (

) Appeals is the only administrative function of the Service with authority to consider settlements of tax controversies and has the primary responsibility to resolve these disputes without litigation to the maximum extent possible. Appeals’ mission is to resolve tax controversies, without litigation, on a basis which is fair and impartial to both the Government and the taxpayer in a manner that will enhance voluntary compliance and public conﬁdence in the integrity and efficiency of the Service. Appeals accomplishes this mission by considering protested and Tax Court cases, holding conferences, and ing settlements in a manner which ensures Appeals employees act in accord with the Taxpayer Bill of Rights (TBOR) in every interaction with taxpayers. See IRC
). See Pub
, Taxpayer Bill of Rights. For more tion, see IRM
, Appeals Operating Directives and Guidelines. (
) The authority delegated to Appeals Team Case Leaders as to their respective cases is found in Delegation Order
(Rev.
), IRM
, Servicewide Poli- cies and Authorities, Delegation of Authorities for the Appeals Process. (

) The Director, Case and Operations Support (COS) is the executive for designing, developing, delivering, and monitoring short and long-range tax administration policies, programs, strategies, and objectives for the Appeals organization. (
) The Director, Policy is responsible for providing technical and procedural guidance to Appeals employees, establishing and maintaining policies and standard procedures for Appeals work streams. (
) The Policy analyst shown on the Product Catalog Information page as the originator is the assigned author of this IRM. (
) Planning, Quality and Analysis (PQA) provides trends and data analyses and detailed summary reports for Appeals. (
) Internal Revenue Manual

Purpose: This IRM section describes the process and procedures for working team cases in Appeals. These cases are received from Large Business and International (LB&I) and are generally assigned to an Appeals Team Case Leader (ATCL). However, in some instances a senior Appeals Officer (AO) is assigned as a team leader. Therefore, these procedures are used by both ATCLs and AOs who are team leaders on a team case.

) This section discusses procedures for working team cases in Appeals. cases are received from Large Business and International (LB&I) and are generally assigned to an Appeals Team Case Leader (ATCL). However, in some instances a senior Appeals Officer (AO) is assigned as team leader. Therefore, these procedures are used by both ATCLs and AOs who are leaders on a team case. (

) A team case work unit generally requires the use of Appeals Officers (AOs) team members in addition to the team case leader. It has a level of and impact characterized by the presence of extremely complex issues in dispute. Each team case work unit involves: a. Signiﬁcant amounts of money at issue, while the determination of cant” is at the discretion of the Appeals Team Manager (ATM), the tax dispute is generally $

million or more; or b. A signiﬁcant number of issues, some of which are highly complex, for team case leader to coordinate. The team case leader generally some of the signiﬁcant issues. The ATM determines whether the work unit contains a signiﬁcant number of issues on a case-by-case basis. (
) See IRM
, Accomplishing the Appeals Mission, for further tion. (

8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines Step Action 3. Determine whether the case is ready for Appeals’ consider- ation. See IRM 8.2.1.5, Returning a Case to Examination - ATE, for more information on grounds for returning a case when it is not ready for Appeals’ consideration. Note: If the ATCL/AO determines that a conference is not appropriate, the ATCL/AO will not send an initial contact letter. Instead, go to IRM 8.7.11.2.1(3), below. 4. Make initial contact. For both non-docketed and docketed cases, the ATCL/AO may make initial contact by letter or by telephone in lieu of using a contact letter. If the ATCL/AO makes initial contact by telephone, during such contact, the ATCL/AO must ensure that the substance of the contact letter is discussed with the taxpayer and documented in CARATS. If the ATCL/AO makes initial contact by letter: • For non-docketed cases, issue contact Letter 5157, Nondocketed Acknowledgement & Conference, or another approved contact letter. • For docketed cases, issue contact Letter 3808, Docketed Acknowledgement and Conference (To Peti- tioner), or Letter 3808-A, Docketed Acknowledgement and Conference (To Counsel of Record). 5. Attempt to settle the case based on factual hazards when the case submitted by the originating function is not fully developed and the taxpayer has provided no new informa- tion or evidence. A fully developed case has all the pertinent evidence well documented with an easy to follow audit trail. Generally, the case contains the evidence needed to support the adjustments proposed in the RAR. ) If the ATCL/AO determines that a conference is not appropriate, in lieu of sending Letter
, Letter
, Letter
-A, or another contact letter, within a reasonable time frame, the ATCL/AO will: • For a premature referral, prepare Letter

, Appeals Referral to amination, secure any additional documentation (if applicable), and submit the case to the ATM for closing. The ATCL/AO will document section in CARATS by inputting AC-OD. • For a full concession case, notify the taxpayer/representative (if ap- propriate), prepare the appropriate closing letter/documents, and the case to the ATM for closing. The ATCL/AO will document this section in the CARATS by inputting DM. (

) The ATM will be reasonable in extending the contact time frame if circum- stances (e.g., leave, workload, case complexity or other priorities) prevent ATCL/AO from meeting them. If the ATM extends the time frame, the will document this decision and the agreed upon time frame in the CAR for case. The statute veriﬁcation time frame shall not be extended beyond calendar days. if the contact time frame is extended beyond
calendar days, then the ATM will contact the taxpayer/representative by providing a status of the case and to whom the case is assigned. (

) The ATCL promotes timely resolution of large complex work units received from LB&I. He/she has settlement authority and is responsible for simultane- ously managing at least two major work units on a continuing basis. (

) An ATCL considers no more than two consecutive cycles of the same unless there has been an intervening cycle considered by an another ATCL AO, or unless there are special circumstances determined by management. (
) After initial discussions between the ATCL and his/her ATM, the ATCL has complete control of the case. (

) The ATCL has settlement authority for all work unit assignments. However, ATCL’s proposal of settlement may be subject to the concurrence of Specialists (Technical Guidance or International) for Coordinated Issues. See IRM

for review and concurrence requirement for Coordinated Issues. The ATCL Team Manager (ATCLTM) may propose a change to the proposed settlement, and if agreement is not reached, the Area Director, Operations, will resolve the issue. Both the ATCL and the ATCLTM will sign Form
, Appeals Transmittal and Case Memo, for all work units. The ATCLTM’s signature on Form
will conﬁrm that the ATCLTM has no proposed changes to the settlement. The ATCL will then counter-sign the closing documents, which include the Form
Note: Because the ATCL has settlement authority on all related work units assigned, cases worked in ATCL Operations are not subject to the in IRM
, Reviewing Official’s Acceptance of Settlement Proposal, and IRM
, Reviewing Official’s Rejection of Settlement Proposal, the related subsections regarding a reviewing official’s approval or rejection of the ATCL’s settlement proposal.
Because the ATCL has settlement authority on all related work units assigned, cases worked in ATCL Operations are not subject to the provisions in IRM
, Reviewing Official’s Acceptance of Settlement Proposal, and IRM
, Reviewing Official’s Rejection of Settlement Proposal, and the related subsections regarding a reviewing official’s approval or rejection of the ATCL’s settlement proposal.
Technical and Procedural (
) The ATCL controls several work units concurrently, depending on their plexity and special characteristics. When appropriate, he/she is assigned complex work units not meeting the criteria in IRM
) above. (

) The ATCL Operations’ office may recommend the establishment of a new position, depending on workload. The position may be ﬁlled temporarily or manently, or may require a detailee. A request to establish a new ATCL position must be submitted for approval to the Chief, Appeals with a tion for establishing the position. (

) A team approach is used in the absence of a formally established ATCL position. Two or more Appeals Officers (AOs) can form a team, pooling ciency to resolve all issues expeditiously. A team leader is assigned when team approach is used. (
) Appeals Officers of any grade are assigned to teams, and support are used as needed. (
) When an LB&I case is assigned to an AO who later determines a team would expedite completion of the work unit, the manager assigns more personnel. (

) Generally, team leaders can consider no more than two consecutive the same taxpayer, unless there has been an intervening cycle considered another AO or unless there are special circumstances determined by ment. (

) The team leader recommends disposition of the work unit. Any reached at an interim level on an issue-by-issue basis between a team of Team member and a taxpayer or representative is tentative and must ﬁt in with ommendations of the team leader who must be fully acquainted with the strengths and weaknesses of issues and their proposed disposition. (

) Team members are responsible for considering their portion of the work signment independently unless the manager believes authority over a member’s issue rests with the team leader. The team leader will ascertain the required concurrence is obtained from Technical Guidance or (
) The team leader and team members are responsible for providing LB&I opportunity to consider and timely review and comment on new evidence presented by the taxpayer. See IRM
, for more and documentation requirements. (

) Periodic team meetings are held to discuss the possible impact of each member’s issues on those of other members, to deﬁne objectives and to otherwise coordinate team activities. The team leader is consulted on and procedural questions consistent with the degree of independence the team members by the team leader. (

) The team leader is responsible for meeting target dates and identifying attempting to eliminate obstacles when problems are encountered by members. Periodically, the team leader’s ATM is updated on the progress informed of any problems that may develop in the case.

Team Cases
) When disagreements/differences arise between team members (including members from Technical Guidance and International), please see IRM
), Accomplishing the Appeals Mission, for additional information. (

) The ATCL has settlement authority on all related work units assigned. However, the ATCLTM may propose a change to the proposed settlement. If there is a disagreement between the ATCL and the ATCLTM and an is not reached, the issue will be resolved by the Area Director. Both the and the ATCLTM will sign Form
for all work units. The ATCLTM’s signature on Form
will conﬁrm that the ATCLTM has no proposed changes to the settlement. The ATCL will then counter-sign the closing documents. (
) Team members are responsible for preparing Appeals Case Memoranda (ACMs) for the issues assigned to them. The team leader coordinates tion of the ACM and Form

except where a case within the work unit is handled entirely by one team member. If the team leader resolves an issue assigned to a non-Technical Guidance or International team member without the member’s agreement, the team leader must prepare the ACM for that issue. If the team leader revises the team member’s ACM, the team leader provide a copy of the revised ACM to the team member within a reasonable time. (
) Team members are responsible for providing the Large Case Quarterly Status Report to the team leader by the
th business day of the month following the end of the quarter. This report is mandatory for all team assigned to ATCL team cases. (

) The team leader is responsible for statute of limitations control except in a multi-case unit where cases are assigned to another team member; then, team member to whom the case is assigned is responsible. (

) Portions of team case leader work units assigned to individual AO team members are graded on the basis of complexity and difficulty of the portion. Team leader control varies and must be considered in determining grade level to assign to a team member’s portion. (
) The tentative grade of a team member’s assignment is determined as if it a work unit standing alone but taking into consideration the expected degree control. (

) The ﬁnal grade of the assignment must reﬂect the actual impact of team control and related limitations on the team member’s responsibility for making, presenting results, and other relevant factors. Depending on the degree actually experienced, those factors may result in a lower ﬁnal assign- ment grade. (
) IRM
, Returning a Case to Examination - ATE, discusses some of the reasons for returning a case. The list is not all inclusive. (
) Regardless of the reason, discussions must be held and an agreement reached between Appeals and LB&I management on actions required by before the case is accepted by Appeals.
(10-26-2007) Grading Team Case Work Assignments

IRM 8.2.1.5, Returning a Case to Examination - ATE, discusses some of the reasons for returning a case. The list is not all inclusive.
Technical and Procedural (
) When assigned a case, immediately examine all returns to determine the statute of limitation expiration date and to verify the expiration date appearing of on the case summary card. See IRM
Note: There must be at least
days remaining on the statute of when the case is received in Appeals. If a case is returned to tion, there must be at least
days remaining on the statute of limitations when the case is received in Examination and at least
days remaining when the case is returned to Appeals. (

) It’s the team leader’s full responsibility for obtaining the proper consents to extend the period of assessments, when necessary, even when a portion of the case is separated and assigned to a team member. Although the team member may take action to extend the statute on his/her assignment, the leader is responsible for assuring the statutes are protected. (

) Because a team leader case generally takes a signiﬁcant period of time to resolve, request statute extensions to cover the time frame. A team leader case assignment may involve numerous corporations, partnerships, etc., must be reviewed to verify any unique statutes. (

) There are many unusual statute situations which require special such as: a. Successors in Interest - If, since the last statute extension, there has been a successor in interest, it is necessary to determine who is autho- rized to sign for the predecessor corporation and it is necessary to determine the proper captions to use. One of the sources for this information is the Board of Directors resolution. It is also advisable consult with local Counsel in making this determination. See IRM

, Merged Corporations, regarding merged corporations. Note: For consolidated income tax returns, one consent will suffice to cover all companies included in the consolidated tax return, but years included on a single consent must be years during which group is considered to have remained in existence. See IRM

, Consolidated Returns, regarding successors for a group of affiliated companies that ﬁled a consolidated return. b. TEFRA Considerations - TEFRA can create complications concerning statutes. See TEFRA IRM
, Appeals Pass-Through Entity Handbook, for additional information on TEFRA cases and IRM

, Appeals Statute Responsibility, for additional information on statutes. c. Reference Returns - If it is determined a consent is unnecessary, a memorandum for the ﬁle (or other approved form) setting out the Attach the original of the memorandum to the return, and give a copy to APS to update ACDS. See IRM

, Cases Where a Consent is Not Necessary. d. Returns Held Off Site - In situations where the original returns are held off site, which is a practice in a number of offices, copies of all POAs, and the front page of the returns must be kept by the team

Appeals Team Cases 8.7.11
8.7.11.6.3 (09-04-2018) Returning a Case to LB&I

These guidelines apply to LB&I-sourced work excluding Primary Business Code (PBC) 315, International Individual Compliance (IIC) cases. Use the following chart to determine when information is returned to LB&I:
8.7 Technical and Procedural
In instances where new information (see Item
or

above), is provided by the taxpayer during Appeals consideration, the ATCL/AO may offer Rapid Appeals Process (RAP) to resolve the Appeals-ready issues (issues that do not require additional analysis or investigative action).

For cases where no issues are yet settled (agreed in principle by Appeals and the taxpayer) at the time new information is received, the ATCL/AO will determine if RAP is appropriate for the unsettled issues (no agreement in principle between Appeals and the taxpayer) and ensure the taxpayer is aware of the RAP option. If the taxpayer and LB&I elect to address the issues using RAP, Appeals will retain jurisdic

tion to resolve those issues. After working the issues via RAP and securing closing or partial agreement forms on the agreed issues, Appeals will release jurisdiction to address the new information or On LB&I
sourced cases where RAP is not being utilized, jurisdiction will be released to address new information or new issues and make a de
termination.

• For cases where no issues are yet settled (agreed in principle by Appeals and the taxpayer) at the time new information is received, the ATCL/AO will determine if RAP is appropriate for the unsettled issues (no agreement in principle between Appeals and the taxpayer) and ensure the taxpayer is aware of the RAP option. If the taxpayer and LB&I elect to address the issues using RAP, Appeals will retain tion to resolve those issues. After working the issues via RAP and securing closing or partial agreement forms on the agreed issues, Appeals will release jurisdiction to address the new information or On LB&I-sourced cases where RAP is not being utilized, jurisdiction be released to address new information or new issues and make a de- termination. • For cases involving unsettled and settled issues at the time new infor- mation is received, the ATCL/AO will determine if RAP is appropriate the remaining issues and ensure the taxpayer is aware of the RAP option. If the taxpayer and LB&I agree to address the issues using Appeals will retain jurisdiction to work those issues. After working the issues via RAP and securing closing or partial agreement forms on the agreed issues, Appeals will release jurisdiction to address the new mation or issue and make a determination. (

) For those cases where the taxpayer provides information in response to a question or request from Appeals to clarify or corroborate information contained or referenced in the RAR, Protest, or Rebuttal or makes a new argument (not including new information), the ATCL/AO will promptly send information package or argument with all supporting information to LB&I, allowing at least
days for written review and comment (subject to ex parte requirements). An extension of time can be granted if mutually agreed. See IRM

, Taxpayer Raises New Theory or Alternative Legal Argument, for procedures on retaining jurisdiction. LB&I handles these requests for review of information on a priority basis and makes additional contact with the taxpayer as necessary to perform a complete review of the additional information. (
) See IRM

, Jurisdiction Released, for procedures on returning a case to the originating function. Note: The office that has jurisdiction of the case at the time of closing will responsible for performing the closing procedures. (
) Generally, team leader cases are assigned to a Large Case Tax Computation Specialist. For purposes of this subsection, the Large Case Tax Computation Specialist is referred to as the TCS. (
) Within

days of assignment of the case to the TCS, the TCS completes a thorough review to verify the accuracy and completeness of the RAR tax putations. The review includes creation of a computer accessible ﬁle (or Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

, Appeals Managers (

Technical and Procedural (
) The team discusses tentative target dates and those issues or procedures which may impede the prompt closing of the case and decide the actions Planning necessary to prevent delay. (

) It is suggested a separate ﬁle be created for each issue. The ﬁle should contain all relevant information regarding that issue, such as sections of Revenue Agent’s Report (RAR), engineer’s report, conference notes, rough draft supporting statements, etc. (

) It is desirable to discuss and agree upon these target dates at the ﬁrst with the taxpayer. The goal is to set ﬁrm dates, agreed to by Appeals and taxpayer, and to resolve speciﬁc issues. Furnish the taxpayer with a list of team members and their respective work assignments. Clearly deﬁne the and authority of the team leader and team members for the taxpayer. (
) Apply the aspects of Fast Track Settlement to the team leader case a means of efficient resolution. (

) The team will discuss and develop a complete list of questions to be addressed by the parties (taxpayer and LB&I) during the pre-conference taxpayer conference. To comply with the ex parte requirements, a copy of questions to the LB&I team must be shared with the taxpayer. (
) After the planning conference is complete, the team leader will complete ACDS Electronic Work Plan (See IRM
) incorporating the reached with the taxpayer or his/her representative. (

) The team leader is responsible for planning and controlling the progress of work unit. Although initial responsibility to follow up (requests for information from taxpayers, requests for information from Headquarters, Justice Department or other sources) lies with the team member assigned segment of work, the team leader monitors this aspect of the team’s (

) The team leader must be involved in the case management practices of all team members. This is accomplished by periodic monitoring, issue reviews, mandatory written feedback, if applicable, or other appropriate techniques. Each team member’s manager ensures the team member maintains a activity record which includes the team member’s contacts with the and all signiﬁcant actions on the case. (

) When faced with complicated technical issues, contact available resources early. For example, obtain input from Counsel, Headquarters, the Appeals Conference Technical Specialist and/or the taxpayer prior to the pre-conference and planning conference. (
) Contact Examination immediately upon case assignment to ensure the team has access to the entire administrative ﬁle on a particular issue for effective discussion at the preconference meeting. (
) Contact the Appeals Technical Specialist for a coordinated issue paper or informal advice on any coordinated issue as early as possible.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
Contact the Appeals Technical Specialist for a coordinated issue paper or informal advice on any coordinated issue as early as possible.

page (

) Ongoing communications, whether in the form of conferences between the team or other communications between Appeals and LB&I are encouraged. Open lines of communication greatly expedite the completion of the case the taxpayer presents new arguments or there are other developments were not anticipated at the time of the pre-conference meeting. Always keep mind ex parte communication provisions do apply. (
) Return the case to LB&I for consideration if the taxpayer presents new mation or evidence. See IRM

, Taxpayer Provides New Information. If Appeals receives a case that is not fully developed and the taxpayer does not provide any new information, attempt to settle the case factual hazards. The case will not be returned for further development. (

) The team conference work plan reﬂects the long-term plan for completion of the work unit with realistic target dates. The participation of the taxpayer’s Work resentative is an integral part of the planning process. Furnish the representative a copy of the plan (consistent with disclosure and privacy statutes). In addition to long-term planning, use the team conference work to outline the next quarter’s contemplated actions on the work unit, including follow-ups. It should reﬂect a plan for further actions and not solely serve as report on work unit status. (

) The team leader is responsible for the preparation and development of the work plan, with participation by all team members. In some instances the plan will be used as the schedule of adjustments. (
) The team leader forwards the work plan to his/her ATM for approval within days after the opening conference. Work plans are kept in the local office available for Area office monitoring. (

) The team leader updates the work plan quarterly, or more frequently when warranted, by noting signiﬁcant progress; new problems encountered and plans for solving them; and any revisions of the overall work plan or target dates, including reasons for such revisions. (

) The ACDS electronic work plan will be utilized by the team leader for all Appeals Team Cases. The format of the electronic work plan ensures the following items are addressed: a. Identiﬁcation of team members; b. A list of unagreed issues and assignments to team members and the responding Uniform Issue List (UIL) codes if required; c. Identiﬁcation of problems or factors that may cause delays and the sponding action plan; d. A projection of when the initial conferences will be held and the mate number of conferences that may be required; and e. A realistic estimated completion date for the work unit. This date is mined only after it has been discussed with both the team members the taxpayer. (
) Some of the above items may not be determinable at the date the work ﬁrst drafted. Add them when reasonably determined as part of the periodic updating of the work plan. (

amination, Competent Authority, Engineering, Technical, etc.,) and proposed solutions; and Actions to be taken in the next quarter, with target dates.

Materiality must be considered in judging whether a working panel is warranted by applying Statement of Financial Accounting Concepts No. 2, which indicates “...no general standard of materiality could be formulated to take into account all the considerations that enter into an experienced human judgment.”
Upon receipt of a case, the ATCLTM will consider whether a screening panel is
page (
) The ATCLTM will assign the case to the ATCL advising that the case may a screening panel. (
) After collaboration with the ATCL, the ATCLTM will make the ﬁnal decision whether a working panel is needed. (
) The screening panel will be a minimum of two ATCLs and the ATCLTM. (
) Selection of the ATCLs will be made by the ATCLTM and may cross ATCL erations’ lines due to resources or ATCL expertise in a speciﬁc issue. (
) The Screening Panel Checksheet will be prepared individually or collectively the screening panel. The ATCLTM and the ATCLs will promote a team ap- proach in preparing the checksheet. (

) The ATCLTM will review the Screening Panel Checksheet from the panel members and make a ﬁnal determination as to whether a working panel is necessary and which issues will be assigned to the working panel. (
) Issues not requiring a working panel will be worked by the ATCL assigned case. (
) The purpose of the working panel is to provide additional resources and points on complex issues. (

) ATCL working panel will provide additional viewpoints and drive high impact issues to resolution. The working panel normally consists of three ATCLs; may serve by exception with management documentation. (
) Consensus decision making will be used by the panel. In the event the cannot come to a consensus, the ATCLTM will assist in facilitating a consensus. (
) If consensus is not reached, the issue will be resolved by the Director, ATCL Operations. (

) There are many beneﬁts of a working panel that include: • ATCLs can help each other resolve issues by sharing knowledge and expertise. • Quality will increase as the most experienced personnel will address most complex issues. • Panel members will have an opportunity to work with others from different demographic backgrounds with various expertise. • ATCLs can utilize informal peer review of settlement strategies prior settlement. • There’s an opportunity to promote teaming concepts and enhance internal controls. • The synergies between the competencies of panel members are promoted. • Equity is promoted because an individual working panel member will be able to direct the outcome of settlement. • Three or two senior Appeals personnel, rather than a single ATCL will interface with the taxpayer’s legal team and Compliance’s team. (
) Internal Revenue Manual
8.7.11.10 (09-04-2018) Working Panel Review Process
Consensus decision making will be used by the panel. In the event the panel cannot come to a consensus, the ATCLTM will assist in facilitating a

ATCLs can help each other resolve issues by sharing knowledge and expertise. Quality will increase as the most experienced personnel will address most complex issues. Panel members will have an opportunity to work with others from different demographic backgrounds with various expertise. ATCLs can utilize informal peer review of settlement strategies prior to settlement. There’s an opportunity to promote teaming concepts and enhance internal controls. The synergies between the competencies of panel members are promoted. Equity is promoted because an individual working panel member will be able to direct the outcome of settlement. Three or two senior Appeals personnel, rather than a single ATCL will interface with the taxpayer’s legal team and Compliance’s team.
Technical and Procedural (
) Each panel member is responsible for the full scope of the issues before the panel. (

) This text establishes guidelines for conferences (pre-conferences) held between Appeals and LB&I on certain protested cases. The pre-conferences Meeting take place prior to Appeals’ meeting with the taxpayer. These guidelines are minimum standards for communication between Appeals and LB&I. (

) The pre-conference procedures apply to all LB&I cases meeting Appeals’ nition of a team case. The procedures may be used for LB&I cases which do not meet the deﬁnition of a team case and for other cases upon election by either LB&I or Appeals. For deﬁnition of a team case, see Introduction to Working Appeals Team Cases found at the beginning of this IRM. (
) The purpose of the conference is to discuss the issues, protest, and LB&I’s written rebuttal to the protest. A frank discussion of the issues adds to of knowledge of the case. Meeting (
) The taxpayer is notiﬁed of, and given an opportunity to participate in, any conference in accordance with requirements involving ex parte communications. (

) The need for any additional resources, specialists or expert witnesses, etc., are discussed at this meeting which serves to establish lines of between Appeals and LB&I that are maintained throughout consideration of case. Always keep the ex parte communication provisions ﬁrmly in mind. (

) LB&I is encouraged to share its views on the disputed issues, including its sessment of litigating hazards and the strategies involved in setting up adjustments on particular issues. However, the conference is not used as a vehicle for securing a commitment from Appeals to defend any particular issues, commit to particular settlement positions, or otherwise “negotiate” the settlement posture of Appeals on the case. (

) Unless an exception is agreed to between LB&I and Appeals, hold a pre- conference on all LB&I cases designated as team leader cases in Appeals. a LB&I may request a conference on other LB&I cases. If LB&I does not Meeting a conference on a LB&I case and Appeals believes a conference would be helpful, Appeals may initiate the conference. (

) The team leader is responsible for arranging the conference. Conferences non-team leader cases are arranged by the team leader following a written request to LB&I for the conference or the receipt of a request for a (

) An Appeals request for a conference must be signed by a team leader or A request from LB&I is initiated by the case manager/group manager (or official as determined by LB&I). A conference request from LB&I should accompany the ﬁle when it is received by Appeals. If Appeals desires a ence, make the request as soon as possible after receipt of the case. (

) If LB&I and Appeals agree a pre-conference is not useful in any case for a conference is required, document the ﬁle with a memorandum signed by propriate officials from each function specifying no pre-conference is desired either LB&I or Appeals. In Appeals, the memorandum must be signed by an ATM or Area Director.

) The post settlement conference is not intended to be a critique of the ment nor is it intended to replace, in any way, LB&I’s “dissent” procedures. IRM

Examples of appropriate discussion in this context include: • Inquiries as to why alternative settlement approaches were not used • Inquiries as to why more weight wasn’t given to a particular fact, argument or sub-argument • Inquiries as to the weight given to a particular document, fact, or sub-argument when the ACM analyzes hazards of litigation on an aggregate or composite basis • Inquiries that are hypothetical or open-ended (
) Post settlement conferences are only available for cases originating from and worked by a team leader in Appeals (ATCL or an AO assigned as a leader). See IRM
) Post settlement conferences can occur at the request of either Appeals or LB&I. (
) If both Appeals and LB&I agree that it is not necessary, the post settlement conference can be waived. (

) The Office of Appeals is an independent and impartial forum for both the ernment and the taxpayer to resolve disputes without litigation, and in so, promotes voluntary compliance by demonstrating the fairness and tiveness of the tax administration system. See IRM
, Accomplishing Appeals Mission. (

) With respect to the prohibition on ex parte communications: a. The Executive Summary is similar to a Summary and Recommendation for an issue; both are brief and up front. In fact, the Executive Summary is the ﬁrst page(s) of a large or complex case ACM. It may include:

of a large or complex case ACM. It may include: a. Background of the taxpayer, industries, foreign sub/parent, products, name changes, stock exchange listing, mergers and acquisitions, etc. If the information to present is lengthy or complex, make the background separate section. b. The most signiﬁcant issues and results. c. Joint Committee jurisdiction or consideration. d. Collection Concerns – accounts receivable dollar inventory (ARDI) con

siderations e. Audit history – prior litigation of the taxpayer, rollover or recurring results of other cycles, carry backs that affect retention rates, etc. f. Technical Guidance/International – identiﬁcation of issues, approval, variances from written positions, etc. g. External assistance – technical advice (formal and informal), competent authority, etc. h. Future years – potential claims, closing agreements, letters of under

standing. i. Provide a discussion of the factors impacting the settlement that subsequent to LB&I completing its consideration, or that are outside the Appeals hazards evaluation. For instance, a change in tax law, new con
trolling case law, or a whipsaw issue that had to be conceded. These
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines
issues need to be noted as items that would have required adjustments to be made by Examination, or in other words, the adjustments would not be the result of an Appeals hazard settlement.
The basic format of the Schedule of Adjustments for large or complex cases is the same, but there may be a need to add “Additional Features.” If the addi

tional columns won’t ﬁt on the page, show the schedule in landscape format to accommodate the extra columns. Here is a list of some items to use in the schedule in addition to those in the standard Schedule of Adjustment:

The basic format of the Schedule of Adjustments for large or complex cases is the same, but there may be a need to add “Additional Features.” If the addi- tional columns won’t ﬁt on the page, show the schedule in landscape format to accommodate the extra columns. Here is a list of some items to use in the schedule in addition to those in the standard Schedule of Adjustment:

schedule in addition to those in the standard Schedule of Adjustment: a. Team member name listed next to their assigned issues is optional. b. Page references to the RAR, protest, and ACM are optional but are helpful and often part of a work plan. c. Identiﬁcation of Technical Guidance/International coordinated issues where applicable. If no Technical Guidance/International issues exist in the case, this column is not needed. However, make an affirmative statement to this effect as a footnote on the Schedule of Adjustments. d. Indicate rollover or recurring issues with a “yes” or “no”, to alert tion of their settlement authority under Delegation Order

Make a complete statement about the delegation authority in the Summary and Recommendation section of the issue discussion. If no rollover or recurring issues exist for a particular case no column is needed, however, make an affirmative statement to this effect as a footnote on Schedule of Adjustments. (
) If the schedule is developed when the case is ﬁrst assigned, it can serve as the basis for the issue status schedule in the large case work plan. (

) The four sections of an ACM: Summary and Recommendation, Brief Back- ground, Discussion and Analysis, and My Evaluation, work for even the most complex of cases. The complexity of the issue dictates the length and of the longer narrative. The following sections give some guidance in your ACM. (

) Prior ACM – Many LB&I subsequent cycles have identical issues. If they are resolved on the same basis as the prior cycle, then it’s appropriate to cite prior ACM rather than repeat the discussion in detail. If such a reference is made, attach a copy of the prior ACM. The Summary and Recommendation section may then be all that is needed in the current ACM. (
) Examination Settlement Authority – If Exam DO
is applicable to the for subsequent cycles, make a complete statement about the delegation authority in this section. (
) Combining Issues - LB&I cases may involve issues that need to be together. If so, combine the discussion into one section. (

) This is the main section for a detailed discussion of any issue. Along with Schedule of Adjustments and the initial framing of the issue, this section serves as the rough draft ACM. Make this section clear and concise by providing yourself and the reader with a blueprint or outline of the discussion follow. In a complex issue discussion, good structure is essential.

However, make an affirmative statement to this effect as a footnote on the Schedule of Adjustments. Indicate rollover or recurring issues with a “yes” or “no”, to alert tion of their settlement authority under Delegation Order

Make a complete statement about the delegation authority in the Summary and Recommendation section of the issue discussion. If no rollover or recurring issues exist for a particular case no column is needed, however, make an affirmative statement to this effect as a footnote on Schedule of Adjustments.

) At the conclusions of a case not worked in IMS, the ATCL uses encrypted e-mail to forward a copy of the ﬁnal ACM and related documents to e-mail address, *AP ATCL ACM@irs.gov. (
) A central point of contact designated by the Director, ATCL Operations, maintains the Outlook mailbox. This individual uses encrypted e-mail to forward copies of the ACM, Form
and related documents to the LB&I mailbox. (

) These procedures are used for docketed cases. LB&I is not expected to and comment on the taxpayer’s petition before receipt of the case by However, Appeals must provide LB&I with a copy of the petition for review comment in every docketed case to which these procedures apply. LB&I reviews the petition to the extent LB&I has knowledge of the facts and in dispute. (

) A key part of the pre-conference meeting is planning the timetables and resources needed to respond to new information presented by the Give recognition to the time frames established by the rules of the Tax setting priorities for the examination of new information and response to taxpayer positions. For limitations and procedures concerning Appeals and LB&I consideration of new issues raised in docketed cases, see IRM Appeals Authority Over Docketed Cases. (

) The team case leader gives appropriate feedback on team member perfor- mance, in a timely manner, to both the team members and their managers. The feedback is a meaningful evaluation of the performance of the team member on the case. The feedback is structured around the critical elements of the team member, to the extent they apply to the work done the case.

The team case leader gives appropriate feedback on team member perfor

mance, in a timely manner, to both the team members and their managers. The feedback is a meaningful evaluation of the performance of the particular team member on the case. The feedback is structured around the critical elements of the team member, to the extent they apply to the work done on the case.
8.7 Technical and Procedural Guidelines

) The feedback is given on an on-going basis and no later than when a team member’s work on the case is substantially completed; for example at the completion of conference activities or at the time the team member prepares the ACM on his or her assigned issues. At a minimum, interim or ﬁnal feedback is provided prior to the team member’s annual appraisal and mid- year review. (

) The ATM of the team member, not the team case leader or team, is respon- sible for appraising the performance of AOs on team case assignments. Although the team leader must provide mandatory written feedback on the case, any written assessments of members’ work performance for purposes of personnel actions is made by the manager. (
) When an AO below the level is given a developmental team member assign- ment, the team leader gives timely oral feedback and provides constructive comments regarding performance.
